text:
Fourth Avenue north from 32nd Street, showing Park Avenue Hotel. 1880.
Ewing Galloway, Photographer.

Fourth Avenue, north on west side from 32nd to 34th Streets. The Park Avenue Hotel, originally built in the 1870's by A.T. Stewart is a semi-charitable organization, on the site of the old N.Y. & Harlem Railway round-house (engine-house). It will stand here till 1925, (see Park Avenue). Compare this with the same view in 1906 (by Brown Bros.), which will show little change beyond better pavement, electrified street-cars, and subway entrances at 33rd Street. The old frame hotel and bar on the S.W. corner of 32nd Street will not be demolished till after 1910. About 1895.

Ewing Galloway, Photographer.

East side of Fourth Avenue north from 32nd Street, showing 71st Regiment Armory at left.
1906.
Brown Brothers, Photographer.
Neg #76?

Park Avenue Hotel, west side of Fourth Avenue, north from 32nd Street.
1906.
Brown Brothers, Photographers.

Fourth Avenue, west side, from 32nd to 34th Streets, showing the old Park Avenue Hotel and the new Vanderbilt Hotel nearing completion. The view is from the roof of the old Fourth Avenue Railway (Metropolitan Railway) carbarns. At the N.W. corner of 34th Street, the first building on that side of Park Avenue, stands the Unitarian Church of the Messiah, later known as the Community Church, erected in 1867. To the right, on the east side of the Avenue opposite the Vanderbilt Hotel, stands the 71st Regiment Armory (1893).

1911.

Looking south on Fourth Avenue from 1Park Avenue at 32nd Street; east side. Skyline of lower Manhattan may be seen faintly in the background.

February 27, 1931.

P.L. Sperr, photographer.
